column4: Hi all!  How do I shut down multiple machines when my UPS signals low battery?
ssh in and run "shutdown -h now" as root, how to trigger that to happen I don't know
The shutdown is automatic on the machine that monitors the UPS, but I have others on the same UPS that also need to be shut down automatically.
Is the one that monitors the UPS also *NIX ?
You could just make a script that whenever it is told by the UPS to shut down it first ssh's into the other boxes and shuts them down
python most likely, don't personally know how to do GUI programming with python thouch
I was thinking of possibly python, but I know almost nothing about it.  Does it come in an interpreted environment, or is it compiled?
Interpreted ( it uses a JIT )
Python looks promising.  There is a turtle-like graphics library/module/whatever-its-called available.
You can set the mount point from nautilus in properties
Log into a failsafe gnome session and change the default resolution to something your monitor supports
It happens with failsafe gnome as well.
Or it can probably be changed in gconf-editor
I'll take a look at gconf-editor
I've got gconf-editor running (finally).  Any suggestions as to what to look for regarding my monitor display issue?
darolu: Blender is the vi of 3D software :)
I'm looking for more of a gedit of 3D software.  However, I'm glad you didn't say blender was the Emacs of 3D software.
Had the word "dumpfile" in the name or in its contents?
it had the word dumpfile in the contents.  I forget the name.
Try "grep -R dumpfile ~/"
diff dir1 dir2
does diff do md5sums, or does it just compare filenames/sizes.
Neither, it compares contents.
Most "professional" audio software uses Jack, which at least in the past has been difficult to setup. If you start with Ubuntu Studio you get Jack (and other nice things) setup by default.
